PETITIONS
Presentation
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
Immigration Detention

More than 400 asylum seekers still remain in Australia's offshore detention system, or have come to Australia under Medevac and been subjected to indefinite detention. The cruel practice set up to 'stop the boats' contravenes Australia's obligations under the Refugee Convention and has outlived its aim. However, the Government continues to pay Papua New Guinea and Nauru (at an annual cost of $4mil. per person) to keep asylum seekers in conditions that have been plagued for eight years by physical violence (including murder), sexual abuse of women and children, allegations of torture by guards, medical neglect leading to death, and high rates of mental health decline, self-harm and suicide attempts. The absurdly expensive and inhumane treatment of innocent people seeking safety here is a disgrace, and must finally be stopped.

We therefore ask the House to: .end the offshore detention system; .release those medically transferred to Australia, and now in indefinite detention; .promptly resettle the asylum seekers in safe countries, including Australia, and .ensure asylum seekers are given adequate social support and the right to work.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. PN0519)
Safety, Compensation and Rehabilitation Act

The changing of the wording of Section 36(1) Safety, Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 1988 by a Department of Government. An action I consider unconstitutional and seemingly supported by Comcare and Attorney Generals Department, which is an exclusive power of Parliament. An action which effectively denies me access to rehabilitation, the ability to gain and maintain employment. Further aggravated by the suggestion of being a terrorist or planning to commit a terrorist act.

1. Prove a written explanation as to why Parliament has allowed a Department to alter the wording of an Act contrary to Section 51 and Section 52 of the Constitution, 2. Issue a direction that the Ministers of Services Australia, Comcare and AGD enter in Alternative Dispute Resolution with the Petitioner in an attempt to find a just resolution and avoid litigation, 3. Issue a Ministerial Direction that Comcare provide the Petitioner with the assistance the SCRA 1988 entitles the Petitioner to, as a person with a Permanent Impairment, 4. Issue a direction that the Departments concerned, Services Australia, Comcare and AGD provide written assurance to comply the Legal Services Directions 2017, waiving reliance on Sections 55ZG(2), 55ZG(3) and 55ZI(2) Judiciary Act 1903, and 5. Provide the Petitioner with written assurance that the Petitioner will suffer no ramifications, indignations or further injury, as a result of seeking resolution to this grievance.
from one citizen (Petition No. PN0520)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): Ministerial responses to petitions previously presented to the House have been received as follows:
Jetstar
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition (EN2558) - a proposed Parliamentary inquiry into the Jetstar booking system. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Travel restrictions put in place to ensure the safety of Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic have had implications for the travel plans of many people. Where travel bookings need to be cancelled due to government restrictions, it is unlikely a consumer will be entitled to a refund under the consumer guarantee provisions of the Australian Consumer Law (ACL).

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has published guidance on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on consumers, which is available at: www.accc.gov.au/consumers/consumer-rights-guarantees/covid-19-coronavirus-information-for-consumers. Consumers are encouraged to review the terms and conditions of any travel bookings to identify if they are entitled to a refund or another remedy. If the travel booking entitles a consumer to a refund, the travel provider is not permitted to change those terms and conditions at a later time to deny a refund.

The Privacy Act 1988 has strict rules about how an organisation can handle personal information. If the petitioners are concerned about how their personal information has been used, they may wish to contact the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner, the independent national regulator for privacy, at: www.oaic.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar(Petition No. EN2558)

subdebateinfo.title: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999

p.span: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 21 June 2021 enclosing Petition EN2667 concerning including provisions within the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (Cth) for the setting of immigration quotas or limits.

The Australian Government's Migration Program is carefully designed to maximise the economic and social benefits to Australia, while also considering the long-term population impacts on state and territory planning and infrastructure. To this end, in 2019, the Government made a series of changes to address the issue of sustainable population growth across Australia, including the establishment of a Centre of Population (the Centre) within the Department of Treasury, in recognition of the need for a single point of analysis to assess, monitor and project changes to Australia's population.

These initiatives are further supported by the publication of Australia's first Population Statement, which can be accessed on the Centre's website at: https://population.gov.au/publications/publications-population-statement.html.

The size and composition of Australia's permanent Migration Program is set on an annual basis. In designing the annual Migration Program, the Department of Home Affairs undertakes a planning process which involves a range of consultation activities with key stakeholders, Commonwealth agencies, state and territory governments, and the public. These consultations seek to better understand the needs and concerns of stakeholders and their views help inform the size and composition of the annual Migration Program.

To support the development of the 2021-22 Migration Program, the Department released a discussion paper titled Planning Australia's 2021-22 Migration Program in January 2021, and subsequently received and considered 193 public submissions.

In addition, formal discussions were undertaken with key stakeholders between December 2020 and January 2021, including participants in the migration advice industry, industry and community groups, academics and researchers, Government representatives, and state and territory government representatives.
I engage the petitioner(s) to participate in future public consultation processes. Thank you for bringing Petition EN2667 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke(Petition No. EN2667)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN2673 on Humanitarian Relief for Global Pandemic Hotspots. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government has been closely following the COVID-19 pandemic, across the world. We recognise the need to work with our neighbours and will provide support to ensure that their vaccine rollouts are safe, quick and effective and our region is able to return to normal as soon as possible.

Australia's five COVID-19 vaccine agreements - with Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Novavax, Moderna and the COVAX Facility - are allowing us to support our Pacific and South East Asian neighbours, as vaccine doses can be donated or on-sold (with no mark-up) to other countries or international organisations, should these vaccines prove safe and effective, and units are available above domestic needs.

The COVAX Facility is another mechanism that the Government is supporting to provide vaccine coverage for our region. The COVAX Facility is co-hosted by Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, the World Health Organization and the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations. It aims to pool purchasing power and risk to develop a diverse portfolio of potential COVID-19 vaccines and fast track manufacture.

On 26 August 2020, Australia announced an investment of $80 million to the Advanced Market Commitment (AMC) of the COVAX Facility, and on 3 June 2021, Australia contributed an additional $50 million, making a total of $130 Million to the COVAX AMC. On 22 September 2020, Australia joined the COVAX Facility with an upfront payment of $123 million separate to the initial $80 million. Australia's contribution to the AMC will support rapid, fair and equitable access to vaccines for 92 eligible lower and lower-middle income countries including most Pacific island countries.

Further enhancing Australia's support for the Pacific, on 31 October 2020, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) announced the creation of the Regional Vaccine Access and Health Security Initiative that will consist of a range of support mechanisms including supplying safe and effective vaccine doses and delivering technical support to our regional partners. The Government has allocated $623 million to this initiative.

The funding will help ensure that the countries of the Pacific and Timor-Leste are able to achieve full immunisation coverage and make a significant contribution toward meeting the needs of Southeast Asia. Work under this initiative has commenced with doses being distributed in Papua New Guinea and Timor-Leste at a weekly rate of 120,000 locally manufactured doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine.

Alongside this, on 12 March 2021, the Government announced the creation of a Quad Vaccine Partnership with the United States, Japan and India to strengthen and assist countries in the Indo-Pacific with vaccination. Australia is contributing $100 million, which will contribute towards the provision of vaccines and "last mile" delivery support with a focus on Southeast Asia.

My Department is working closely with DFAT, and appropriate overseas authorities in the Pacific and South East Asia to ensure that this funding ensures the best-possible outcomes for health and wellbeing and that the vaccines are assessed rigorously to ensure that they are safe, efficacious and of a high quality.
No country can truly emerge from this pandemic until all countries have access to safe, effective and affordable COVID-19 vaccines, and the Government is committed to ensuring this for our region.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2673)
COVID-19: Cruise Industry
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 9 August 2021 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP, concerning petition EN2683 calling on the Australian Government to lift the ban on foreign flagged ships to allow the resumption of cruises in Australia and to include them in future 'travel bubbles'. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

I acknowledge the contribution the cruise industry makes to the Australian economy, and the impact the COVID-19 pandemic has had on the industry and the broader tourism sector, particularly in regional areas.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to adopt a four-phase National Plan to transition Australia's national COVID response. Each phase of the plan will be triggered by reaching vaccination thresholds as based on scientific modelling. The resumption of cruise operations and other discretionary forms of travel is being considered in the context of the National Plan. International cruising is part of these considerations.

The resumption of cruising will be dependent on the capacity of state and territory health systems to respond to outbreak events, and the broader epidemiological situation in Australia. Any relaxation of requirements Will be dependent on expert health advice and may be amended or reinstated at any time.

My Department is aware that cruising operations have resumed in some countries overseas. COVID-19 continues to represent a severe and immediate threat to human health in Australia and internationally. Cases internationally continue to grow, and the public health risk posed by international travel remains high.

The human biosecurity emergency period, including the cruise ship ban, is currently in place until 17 December 2021. These restrictions are based on the advice of the Chief Medical Officer and the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC). Advice concerning the emergency period and related restrictions such as the cruise ship ban are regularly reviewed by AHPPC and will be refined to respond to changes in the global and domestic situation as appropriate.

Above all, AHPPC will need to be assured that cruise ships can operate in a COVID-safe way and that the risk of outbreak events impacting the Australian community and our health system is acceptably low before increased cruise operations will be permitted in Australian waters.

The Government will continue to work closely with national health committees, state and ·territory governments, and the cruise industry to ensure that any return to cruise operations meets community expectations regarding the safety of guests, crew and the broader community.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2683)
Agriculture Industry
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 9 August 2021 referring petition EN2687, which seeks a transition to regenerative agriculture practices to ensure healthy soils for a healthy future.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting on-farm biodiversity, sustainable and resilient agricultural practices, education and improving the health of Australia's soil, A range of programs managed by the Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment (the department) address the concerns raised in the petition and demonstrates the commitment of the government to supporting agricultural productivity and resilience,

In the 2021-22 Budget, the government committed $214.9 million to Implement the National Soil Strategy (the strategy), which sets out how Australia will value, manage and improve its soil over the next 20 years. Work is already underway to realise the vision of the strategy to ensure Australia's soil resources are recognised and valued as a key national asset.

The funding to support the strategy includes a program for soil extension services and the development of a soil practitioner accreditation program. The extension program will ensure advice given to farmers and land managers will enable them to better manage their land to Increase resilience and productivity, make informed decisions on agricultural chemical usage and increase soil health. The new education accreditation in soil science will be developed by Soil Science Australia to improve the knowledge of soil professionals and support best practice for managing soil health.

Regenerative agriculture and holistic land management principles and methods, along with other sustainable farming approaches that protect our soil, water and biodiversity resources, have long been incorporated into the ethos and delivery of the $1 billion National Landcare Program (NLP). The NLP is supporting farmers, Landcare groups, research organisations, farming systems groups and state and local governments to develop, trial and extend the on-farm benefits of adopting sustainable farming practices. This includes support for over 100 projects covering regenerative agriculture activities in cropping, grazing and mixed enterprise systems across Australia. The Future Drought Fund Drought Resilience Natural Resource Management program has similarly committed $13.4 million to 80 projects which support innovative land practices.

My Agriculture Stewardship Package aims to encourage on-farm biodiversity and develop market mechanisms to reward farmers for biodiversity services. One of the pilot programs currently being developed under the package is the Australian Farm Biodiversity Certification Scheme. This voluntary scheme will allow Australian farmers to showcase best practice natural resource management to sustain and build biodiversity. Biodiversity certification could help improve the profitability of farm businesses by supporting access to markets, creating price premiums for their produce, lowering capital costs and giving farmers access to information about ways of improving land management practices.

More than $363.8 million is also being invested through the Reef Trust into a range of activities to address water quality in the Great Barrier Reef catchment. This includes repairing gullies and preventing soil loss by addressing streambank erosion, along with building farmer capacity to improve land management practices.

Outside the work of my department, the government continues to raise awareness of the vital role soil plays through the appointment of the National Soil Advocate, the Hon Penelope Wensley AC. Ms Wensley's role provides strong leadership and advocacy on the importance of conserving and improving the health of Australia's soils.

The Cooperative Research Centre on High Performance Soils was established in 2017 to give farmers the knowledge and tools they need to make decisions on extremely complex soil management issues. The CRC is bridging the gap between soil science and farm management to ensure soil performance is increased in the short- and long-term.

Improving soil carbon has multiple benefits, from increasing agricultural productivity to mitigating the effects of climate change via carbon sequestration. Soil carbon sequestration is one available methodology under the Emissions Reduction Fund (ERF). Reducing the cost of measuring soil carbon, to make it more economically viable for farmers to participate in the ERF, is one of the stretch goals announced under the government's Technology Investment Roadmap.
The government also continues to invest in the best agricultural research and development to ensure our farmers have access to the latest science, including as it relates to improving soil health.

Australia's rural research and development corporations (RDCs) have helped drive agricultural innovation since 1989. They allow the government and primary producers to co-invest in R&D to deliver benefits to industries and regional communities. For example, the Grains Research and Development Corporation is focussing on key objectives to improve yield and yield stability, maintain and improve price, and optimise input costs. Better soil management is a key component to deliver this.

CSIRO has been at the forefront of Australia's soil research for decades. Its scientists have contributed world-leading science, for example, to better understand and improve how our farmers can increase carbon in their soil and participate in emissions reduction efforts. CSIRO has also been instrumental in establishing tools and systems to better understand Australia's soil and contribute vital data and information to inform other research, including establishing the Australian Soil Resource Information System, the digital SoilMapp, and through the National Soil Archive.

Finally, agricultural chemical legislation requires that all chemical products supplied to the market must have a label containing adequate instructions for the safe and effective use of a chemical product. Following these instructions helps maximise the product's effectiveness and minimises risks to the environment. Broader government actions will support Australia's agricultural industries by assisting Australian farmers to make informed decisions on their pest and disease management needs and will protect our natural environment into the future.
Thank you for bringing this Petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud(Petition No. EN2687)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 9 August 2021 concerning Petition EN2693 to include visiting family as a "compassionate" or "compelling" reason to leave the country.

I understand the frustration many Australians are feeling by not being able to visit their families overseas during this COVID-19 pandemic. At this time, the Australian Government is not considering including visiting family as a "compassionate" or "compelling" reason to leave Australia. This is in line with the National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response. However, the Government is committed to reviewing this measure regularly that considers the latest medical advice.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared a human biosecurity emergency in relation to the global outbreak of the listed human disease 'human coronavirus with pandemic potential (COVID-19) under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act). During a human biosecurity emergency period, in accordance with section 477 of the Act, the Health Minister may determine requirements that they consider are necessary to prevent or control the entry into, or the emergence, establishment or spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory or part of Australian territory. The Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) (Overseas Travel Ban Emergency Requirements) Determination 2020 (Overseas Travel Ban) is one of those requirements under section 477 of the Act.

COVID-19 continues to represent a severe and immediate threat to human health in Australia. COVID-19 has the ability to cause high levels of morbidity and mortality, and to disrupt the Australian community socially and economically. The impacts of COVID-19 (including the new dangerous variants) continue to challenge Australia, with overseas acquired cases, local outbreaks, community transmission, hotel quarantine transmission, ever-changing high risk countries and countries of acquisition, and Australia's low vaccination rate and staged rollout being factors for consideration.

Managing outbound travel volume is one of the effective ways the Government has been able to moderate pressures on Australian quarantine and health system capacity to date and continues to be an important mechanism for controlling the spread of COVID-19 in the Australian community.

The Overseas Travel Ban continues to have an important role in reducing unnecessary and avoidable burden on Australia's public health and quarantine system, as returning international travellers are required to enter quarantine for 14 days on arrival each time they enter Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2693)
Racism
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 enclosing Petition EN2720 concerning racism in Australia.

Australia is the most successful multicultural country in the world. Research from the highly respected Scanlon Foundation Research Institute's Mapping Social Cohesion Report for 2020, shows Australians are united and optimistic about our future and have the highest level of trust in one another in more than a decade.

Even with the great challenges Australians faced during 2020, particularly the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2020 Scanlon Mapping Social Cohesion Report indicates the strong cohesion of the Australian community. The Report details Australians' trust in one another increased substantially during the pandemic, and that most people agree that immigration and multiculturalism are good for Australia.

Support for multiculturalism increased in 2020 compared to previous years with 84 per cent of surveyed participants agreeing that multiculturalism was good for Australia, and 82 per cent of respondents disagreed with discrimination on the basis of race in selection of immigrants.

The Australian Government condemns racism, which has no place in our cohesive, multicultural society. The Government is investing heavily in Australia's social cohesion, including $63 million in the 2020-21 budget for measures to keep Australians together.

On 16 March 2021, the Australian Race Discrimination Commissioner, Chin Tan announced plans to develop a National Anti-Racism Framework (NARF). I met Commissioner Tan on 17 March 2021 and welcomed his proposals for a NARF. Commissioner Tan has made a detailed set of proposals for Government to consider and I have asked the Department of Home Affairs to work further on these proposals with Commissioner Tan and agencies including the Attorney-General's Department.

The Government is advised by the Australian Multicultural Council (AMC) about multicultural affairs, social cohesion and integration policy and programs. This includes how to build stronger and more cohesive communities and ways of addressing barriers to participation, including racism and discrimination.

The Government also works closely with the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils of Australia, the national peak body representing Australia's culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) communities. Through this partnership, the views and concerns of CALD communities are brought to the attention of the Government.
Thank you bringing Petition EN2720 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke (Petition No. EN2720)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN2722. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation and has always stated that receiving a COVID-19 vaccination would be voluntary. Immunisation is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and accepted by National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public health orders. States and territories are able to issue public health directions requiring individuals to be vaccinated, as is the case where individuals entering aged care facilities must be vaccinated against influenza, except if vaccination is not available to the person or they have a medical contraindication. Some states and territories have now issued public health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people working in other high-risk workplaces. This is a matter for them.

Workplace occupational health and safety is a matter for individual employers and providers. Under model work health safety laws, employers are required to manage risks of viral exposure and infection, and persons at a workplace are required to comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction in that regard.

I understand that some businesses are considering whether they may require people to be vaccinated as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information, such as a person's vaccination status. In each case, businesses will need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their particular workplace.
Anyone with questions about the benefits of being vaccinated is encouraged to talk to their doctor or health professional.
Thank you for writing on this matter
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2722)
International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 enclosing Petition EN2736 seeking to allow overseas travel for permanent residents and citizens to visit family members. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

As you know, until further notice, travel restrictions are in place prohibiting Australian citizens and permanent residents from leaving Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM or authorised decision-makers.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

I acknowledge the difficulties with respect to extended families seeking to reunite. However, the current travel restrictions are in place to manage the health risks posed to the broader Australian community by international travellers.

On 2 July 2021, the National Cabinet agreed to temporarily reduce the current international passenger arrival caps to manage the pressure on quarantine facilities managed by state and territory governments which came into effect from 14 July 2021.

Noting that Australian citizens and permanent residents do not need an exemption to return to Australia, it is imperative that international travel to, and from Australia is permitted for very limited circumstances only, as per the current exemption categories.

You can be rest assured that the Australian Government remains committed to review Australia's travel restrictions policy, as national and global circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve.

In line with this commitment, on 30 July 2021, the National Cabinet agreed, in-principle, to an updated four-step National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response that provides a graduated pathway to transition Australia's COVID-19 response from its current pre-vaccination settings to post-vaccination settings.

As outlined in this plan, easing travel restrictions and large scale reopening of our international borders will be triggered by the achievement of vaccination thresholds of both the nation, and the individual state or territory expressed as a percentage of the eligible population based on expert advice. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2736 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews(Petition No. EN2736)
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 9 August 2021 concerning petition EN2759 expressing support for a greater voice for Indigenous people, and the Uluru Statement from the Heart.

I believe that substantial change can be achieved when Indigenous Australians are providing advice and making decisions on the issues that affect them. In relation to the Indigenous Voice, a robust 18-month co-design process to develop proposals for Local & Regional Voices and a National Voice has recently concluded. Co-design groups, made up of 52 members - the majority of who are Indigenous people - have led this process to design the detail of an Indigenous Voice. Over 9,400 people have had their say on the proposals.

I received the Final Report in July 2021. This is a significant report that comprehensively details the proposals and the deliberations of the co-design process, and it deserves thorough consideration by the Government. The importance of this report and what it means for Indigenous Australians means it is too important to rush this consideration process. We want to get this right.

The Government remains committed to holding a referendum to recognise Indigenous Australians in the Constitution, once there is consensus on the way forward. To successfully bring about constitutional change, Australians must clearly understand and support the proposed amendments. Only eight out of 44 past referenda have been successful and it is important we learn from this and agree to a set of words that are acceptable to the majority of Australians. We must be pragmatic and consider options that provide the greatest chance of success.

With respect to proposals for a treaty with Indigenous nations, I note the ongoing work on agreement-making, both as part of native title settlements and the treaty-related processes in Victoria, Queensland, Tasmania, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Any questions regarding agreement or treaty processes within a state or territory should be directed to that jurisdiction.

The Government is committed to truth-telling at the national level by working in partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and communities; and local, state and territory governments, to support reconciliation and to acknowledge and understand our nation's history.
Thank you for sharing these views.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt(Petition No. EN2759)
Social Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2763, originally directed to the Treasurer, about fake or defamatory online reviews of businesses. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

In response to a direction from the Australian Government, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission released a major report on digital platforms in July 2019. This report contained 23 recommendations including about resolving disputes between digital platforms and businesses and consumers.

In its response to the ACCC's report, the Government agreed to consider the adequacy of internal dispute resolution frameworks of digital platforms. The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications is currently undertaking a study to understand the dispute resolution processes of digital platforms, and user experiences with those processes. The Department will use information collected through this work to inform the Government's further consideration of these issues.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN2763)
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021, enclosing Petition EN2770, concerning priority processing and automatic travel exemptions for the temporary employer sponsored visa programs. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I am the Minister responsible for the matter raised.
Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia.

As you are aware, on 2 July 2021, the National Cabinet agreed to temporarily reduce the current international passenger arrival caps to manage the pressure on quarantine facilities managed by state and territory governments which came into effect from 14 July 2021.

It is therefore imperative that decisions made to grant individual exemptions, or include additional categories for an automatic exemption from the travel restrictions remains supportive of the intent of the travel exemptions program, and facilitate the safe return of Australians who remain stranded overseas.

We acknowledge that this is a challenging and difficult time for Australian businesses who have gone through the process of sourcing skilled individuals from overseas. However, the travel restrictions are in place to protect the broader Australian community from the health risks posed by international travellers.

I would like to assure Australian businesses that the Australian Government remains committed to review Australia's travel restrictions policy, as national and global circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve.

In line with this commitment, on 30 July 2021, the National Cabinet agreed, in-principle, to an updated four-step National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response that provides a graduated pathway to transition Australia's COVID-19 response from its current pre-vaccination settings to post-vaccination settings.

As outlined in this plan, easing travel restrictions and large scale reopening of our international borders will be triggered by the achievement of vaccination thresholds of both the nation, and the individual state or territory expressed as a percentage of the eligible population based on expert advice. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.

Whilst the travel restrictions remain in effect, it is open to employers and businesses, to contact the Department of Home Affairs' critical skills travel exemptions processing team for any travel exemption enquiries, through the online form at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/departmental-forms/online-forms/enquiry-form-businesses-in-critical-sectors.

Section 499 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act), enables the Minister personally to give written directions regarding the performance of functions under the Act or exercising powers under the Act. These directions can outline the order of consideration for certain skilled migration visa applications. Attached are the following Ministerial Directions from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alex Hawke MP, in relation to the Subclass 482 (Temporary Skill Shortage) and Subclass 494 (Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional)) visa programs:
• Ministerial Direction 92 'Order of Consideration - Certain Skilled Migration Visas', which commenced on 7 July 2021.

• Ministerial Direction 93 'Order of Priority Allocation within the Subclass 482 (Temporary Skill Shortage) visa program and Subclass 457 (Temporary Work (Skilled)) visa program', which commenced on 7 July 2021.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2770 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews(Petition No. EN2770)
COVID-19: Quarantine
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP, concerning Petition EN2782 about the abolishment of hotel quarantine and introducing home quarantine for fully vaccinated returning travellers from overseas. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I regret the delay in responding.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for managed quarantine arrangements under their own public health legislation. This enables jurisdictions to best manage their public health response to COVID-19. On 5 February 2021, National Cabinet agreed that hotel quarantine will continue to be the model used to quarantine returning Australians.

The Australian Government continues to review arrangements for quarantine and takes into account the latest scientific knowledge about COVID-19. This includes the impact of COVID-19 vaccination on the transmission of disease. Until further information is available, the Government will not be in a position to make a decision on whether an individual's vaccination status will facilitate changes to public health measures such as quarantine. Until such evidence is available, travellers to Australia will continue to be required to undertake mandatory 14-day quarantine at their first port of arrival, regardless of vaccination status.

On 9 July 2021, National Cabinet agreed to commence pilots of home quarantine for fully vaccinated travellers who had been vaccinated in Australia, with an Australian approved vaccination, arriving from low-medium risk countries. Both South Australia and New South Wales have committed to trial home quarantine options for fully vaccinated cohorts, including trialling different quarantine periods. It is anticipated that home quarantine will become increasingly used as Australia progresses through the National Transition Plan, however some high-risk travellers may need to undergo time-limited managed quarantine for some time. Pilots will be evaluated to inform future options under the National Transition Plan.

State and territory jurisdictions will continue to be responsible for quarantine oversight, including the conduct of further pilot programs when it is clear this will not compound the risk to the community and to the capacity of health systems.

National Cabinet will be continuing to closely monitor the course of current outbreaks and vaccination rates to carefully weigh the risks for state and territory health systems against the opportunity for further trials.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2782)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN2794 to ban COVID-19 vaccine passports and certificates. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government has not made any decisions around the use of mandatory vaccination certificates. States and territories have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health measures within their jurisdiction. As such, states and territories may require proof of COVID-19 vaccination when considering travel exemptions for interstate travel during state-determined lockdowns and travel restrictions.

Australians can already provide voluntary proof of vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting the Australian Immunisation enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.

The Government, through Services Australia and my Department, has also developed a safe and secure COVID-19 Digital Certificate which may help Australians provide proof of vaccination if its required. The certificate is already available through the Medicare Express app for those who wish to use it.

The Government, through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, is also considering the development of a secure digital vaccination certificate that may be used internationally, taking into account the need to adhere to emerging international standards and strict privacy controls.

Apart from select high-risk workplaces and professions, COVID-19 vaccination in Australia largely remains voluntary and individuals may choose to vaccinate. The Government will continue to work with the states and territories to ensure a nationally consistent approach for mandating COVID-19 vaccination. Where COVID-19 vaccination has been mandated for identified high-risk groups through state and territory legislation, exemptions are available for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.
It is important that everyone who can be vaccinated, does, to help keep themselves and others safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt(Petition No. EN2794)
Member for Mitchell
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 18 August 2021 regarding Petition EN2797, which requests that the House of Representatives refer the Hon Alex Hawke MP, Federal Member for Mitchell, to the High Court to determine his eligibility to sit in Parliament. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition. ·

Following a number of High Court cases concerning parliamentarians who were dual citizens and section 44(i) of the Constitution in 2017 and 2018, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters considered reform options for section 44. The Committee's report, published in May 2018, is accessible online here:
https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters/Inquiry_into_matters_relating_to_Section_44_of_the_Constitution/Report_1.

Following that report, the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended to require candidates for federal elections to submit a qualification checklist when nominating. Also, the House of Representatives and the Senate adopted resolutions introducing a procedure for a Committee of the relevant House to investigate issues concerning a parliamentarians' citizenship before the House refers a question about their qualifications for determination by the High Court.
Accordingly, a decision on whether to investigate the qualifications of a Member of the House of Representatives is a matter for the Standing Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash(Petition No. EN2797)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN2828. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

Vaccination for COVID-19 is voluntary - as are all vaccinations in Australia - and everyone maintains the option to choose. However, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and accepted by National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public health orders, effective 17 September 2021.
At this time, an individual is not required to be vaccinated against COVID-19 to be eligible for any Australian Government payment, benefit, scheme, or program.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a public health emergency, and states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice.

In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people working in other high-risk workplaces and for some community activities.

Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons. Businesses, workers and others must comply with public health orders, with significant fines possible for any breaches.

Some employers and businesses have started to mandate vaccinations for their employees working in a high-risk workplace, and for their patrons. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions, and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises.

Anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses will need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their particular workplace.
The Government continues to provide guidance to businesses on these matters, and to encourage vaccination uptake by communicating about the safety, science and benefits of COVID-19 vaccination.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2828)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 23 August 2021 concerning petition EN2858 to stop the experimental COVID19 vaccines without 'informed consent'.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Australian Government. Decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Government is working closely with the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), ATAGI, and all state and territory health departments to ensure that monitoring of COVID-19 vaccine safety is of the highest possible standard in Australia.

The TGA formally assesses the safety, quality, and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and/or disease.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines, like some overseas jurisdictions.

The TGA is open and transparent about safety information relating to COVID-19 vaccines, including any suspected side effects or potential safety issues. The TGA publishes a weekly safety report, including information about reported suspected side effects, as well as other safety alerts as required. More information can be found at: www.tga.gov.au using the search terms 'COVID-19-vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'.
Product information and consumer medicines information, including ingredient listings for all provisionally approved vaccines, can also be located on the TGA's website.

The goal is to protect all people in Australia from the harm caused by COVID-19 infection, through preventing serious illness and death, and where possible, disease transmission. The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven, through approval and safety monitoring processes, to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation, and death.

The TGA is responsible for the ongoing monitoring of all vaccines approved for use in Australia and has robust procedures in place to investigate any potential new safety issues. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.

Use of approved COVID-19 vaccines is not experimental, but does still require the health professional administering the vaccine to obtain consent. They must ask the person if they consent to be vaccinated. They will also explain why they should get the vaccine, why it is safe, what the process entails, and offer their time to answer questions about any part of the vaccination process.

COVID-19 vaccination has not been made mandatory in Australia by the Government, and individuals maintain the option to choose. However, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in certain, high-risk settings. Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees, where they are working in a high-risk workplace, such as healthcare.

The Government continues to provide guidance to businesses on these matters, and to encourage vaccination uptake by communicating about the safety, science, and benefits of COVID-19 vaccination. Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines is following the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. This can be viewed on my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2858)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN2882 - No AstraZeneca for anyone especially over 60.

The safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Australian Government. For this reason, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

Priority groups for vaccination have been identified by considering current public-health, medical and epidemiological evidence on who would be most at risk of contracting COVID-19, or of serious illness if they contracted COVID-19. Vaccines are being administered based on these priority groups, the ATAGI recommendations on preferred vaccines for certain age cohorts, and the supply of vaccines.

Based on emerging data relating to the increased risk of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS) following the AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) vaccine in those aged under 60 years, the ATAGI recommends that the Pfizer (Comirnaty) vaccine be preferred over the AstraZeneca vaccine in that age cohort. Access to the Pfizer vaccine has been limited to preserve supply for this younger cohort, for whom it is the only COVID-19 vaccine currently recommended. The recent approval by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TOA) of the Moderna vaccine - which, like Pfizer, is also an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine - will improve supply and access by the end of 2021.

For people aged 60 years and over, there are different risks, benefits and health needs in relation to vaccination compared to people under 60 years. For those aged 60 years and over, the individual benefits of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine are greater than in younger people. The risks of severe outcomes or death from COVID-19 increase with age, and are particularly high in older, unvaccinated individuals. At the same time, the AstraZeneca vaccine is highly effective at preventing death and severe illness among people who have contracted COVID-19, and the incidence of TIS is very rare. The benefit of preventing COVID-19 through AstraZeneca vaccination outweighs the risk of TIS in this age group.
The evidence the ATAGI has provided on this blood clotting syndrome suggests it is slightly more common, though still extremely rare, in younger people. No other risk factors have been detected.

The ATAGI has recommended that the Pfizer vaccine is preferred over the AstraZeneca vaccine for people aged over 60 years who have some rare conditions or contraindications. Where an individual has a demonstrable need to receive the Pfizer vaccine instead of the AstraZeneca vaccine, which is in line with advice from the ATAGI, this option will be made available to them.

Australia has made a full and thorough assessment of the Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Moderna and Janssen COVID-19 vaccines. The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) provisionally approved these vaccines after a complete assessment of all the available data. This is the same process as any vaccine approved in this country. The TGA will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective.

No part of the process has been rushed, and there was no emergency authorisation granted. The TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines. Some countries are using Emergency Use Authorisations (such as the United Kingdom, United States and Canada) to urgently give vaccines. This is because of the large number of COVID-19 cases and risk in those countries.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers and developers are prioritising the progress of COVID-19 vaccines. This has allowed countries to deliver safe and effective vaccines sooner than before. In this way, the TGA has engaged early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data. This means that the TGA can assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than at the end of the three clinical trial phases. This speed up the review process.
There has been significant investment in research and manufacturing facilities including unprecedented levels of funding, as the pandemic is a global priority.
Furthermore, new technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus much easier. This has allowed them to start working on vaccine design faster.

The Government encourages everyone to be vaccinated as soon as they are eligible. It remains voluntary and the Government respects a person's choice to make an informed decision on whether to participate in Australia's COVID-19 vaccine rollout.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN2882)
Social Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 23 August 2021, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN2904, which requests identity verification for all social media accounts.
The Australian Government is committed to keeping all Australians safe online and recognises that anonymous and fake accounts can be used to create and spread online abuse.

The petition requested that the House of Representatives address the use of anonymous accounts by introducing 100 points of identification checks on social media accounts used by Australians. This request is similar to recommendation 30 of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs report into family, domestic and sexual violence. The Government received this report in March 2021 and is considering its response.

Signatories to the petition expressed concern that anonymous accounts are used to perpetrate online harms such as cyberbullying and posting disturbing imagery. I am pleased to advise that on 23 June 2021 the Australian Parliament passed the Online Safety Act 2021(the Act) which will come into force in January 2022. It will provide the eSafety Commissioner with stronger information-gathering and investigative powers to unmask anonymous accounts. The Commissioner will be able to require that social media service providers, like Facebook and Twitter, provide contact information about users who take advantage of the anonymity of the internet to engage in cyberbullying, cyber-abuse or the non-consensual sharing of intimate images.

The Act will also establish a set of Basic Online Safety Expectations. These expectations will include that service providers enforce their terms of use and take reasonable steps to prevent anonymous accounts being used to post material or conduct activity that may be unlawful or harmful. Services will face financial penalties of up to $555,000 if they fail to report on their actions to uphold the expectations.

The petition also expresses concerns that fake accounts are used to spread fake news (or misinformation). The Government is committed to addressing harms that arise from false, misleading and deceptive online content. That is why, in response to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's 2019 Digital Platforms Inquiry, the Government tasked the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) with overseeing the development of a voluntary industry code on disinformation and news quality. The Code was drafted by DIGI, an industry association representing the digital industry in Australia.

Earlier this year, DIGI released the Australian Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation Code. Twitter, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Apple, Adobe, Redbubble and TikTok have adopted the Code. If platforms' measures to address misinformation under the Code are inadequate, Government will consider if further action is needed.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN2904)
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 9 August 2021 concerning petition PN05l2 which expresses support for the Uluru Statement from the Heart.

In line with the recommendations of the 2018 Joint Select Committee on Constitutional Recognition relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, the Morrison Government supports finalising co-design of a Voice ahead of consideration of options for the legal form of that Voice.

A robust 18-month co-design process to develop proposals for Local & Regional Voices and a National Voice has recently concluded. Co-design groups, made up of 52 members, the majority of who are Indigenous people, have led this process. Over 9,400 people have had their say on the proposals.

I received the Final Report from the co-design groups in July 2021. This is a significant report that comprehensively details the proposals and the deliberations of the co-design process, and it deserves thorough consideration by the Government. The importance of this report and what it means for Indigenous Australians means it is too important to rush this consideration process. We want to get this right.

I note there are many views on constitutional recognition for Indigenous Australians. The Government remains committed to holding a referendum to recognise Indigenous Australians in the Constitution, once there is consensus on the way forward.

To successfully bring about constitutional change, Australians must clearly understand and support the proposed amendments. Only eight out of 44 past referenda have been successful and it is important we learn from this and agree to a set of words that are acceptable to the majority of Australians. We must be pragmatic and consider options that provide the greatest chance of success.

On the matter of a Makarrata Commission, in 2018 the Joint Select Committee on Constitutional Recognition relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders considered the Referendum Council's position to oversee agreement-making and noted that there are a range of views regarding the process and meaning of Makarrata. The Government does not support the establishment of a Makarrata Commission.

On the related matter of truth-telling, this is not a contest of ideas but a sharing of the truth. The Government supports truth-telling at the national level by working in partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and communities and local, state and territory governments, to support reconciliation and to acknowledge and understand our nation's history.
Thank you for sharing these views.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Affairs, Mr Wyatt (Petition No. PN0512)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 30 August 2021, on behalf of the signatories of petition PN0517, concerning the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).
The Australian Government recognises the importance of the ABC and the role it plays in contributing to a sense of national identity, informing and entertaining audiences.

The ABC has more funding certainty than any other media organisation in Australia. Taxpayers provide the ABC with more than $1 billion in funding every year. This is a substantial investment of public funds in our national broadcaster to enable it to provide television, radio and digital media services in line with its Charter.

It is not true that the ABC's budget has been cut. ABC funding is locked in for the current three year period or triennium (2019-20 to 2021-22) and rises each year within that period. In the 2019-20 Federal Budget the ABC received a further $43.7 million for regional and local newsgathering.

The Government provided funding to the ABC of $1,046 million in 2018-19; in the three years of the current triennium, the ABC is receiving $1,062 million (2019-20); $1,065 million (2020-21); and $1,070 million (2021-22). These figures are set out in the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications 2021-22 Portfolio Budget Statement, May 2021, on page 138. Far from a cut, the funding rises each year.

All media organisations are operating in a tough environment - the ABC is not immune. Audience tastes are changing, and new technology and competition from international streaming platforms has transformed viewing habits. Australian media companies are responding to this challenging environment in a variety of innovative ways to reduce the cost of broadcasting infrastructure and back office services.

Under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (ABC Act), the ABC has a responsibility to operate efficiently and to deliver the best possible outcomes for all Australians. It is important that the ABC demonstrates to the Australian people that they are managing the Corporation with a clear strategy that aligns with its Charter and are deploying their resources efficiently.

The 2018 National Broadcasters Efficiency Review found that the national broadcasters could achieve cost efficiencies in a number of areas including by focusing on core business, modernising work practices, and increasing collaboration and sharing. The petitioners can read the report here:
www.communications.gov.au/sites/default/files/2018-national-broadcasters-efficiency-review-redacted.pdf.

The content and operational independence of the ABC is enshrined in legislation. Parliament has guaranteed this independence so that the ABC's decisions are free of political interference. Under this arrangement, how the ABC spends the money allocated to it is a matter for the ABC Board and Executive.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. PN0517)
PETITIONS
Statements

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): In contrast to last week's presentation, which had 153 petitions, this presentation has only two. The combination of the sitting pattern and the four-week period that e-petitions are open to collect signatures means that only paper petitions with handwritten signatures are being presented today.

The committee meets each Wednesday that the House sits to consider and certify petitions, and at other times when there is a long break between sittings. Paper petitions are provided to the committee for certification with signatures already collected, and can therefore be presented at the next opportunity, whereas the presentation of certified e-petitions cannot occur until their signature collection period has passed.

There are currently 163 e-petitions open for collecting signatures. These were certified by the committee at meetings held over the past weeks and will be presented when the House next sits in November. Another large presentation of petitions is expected at that time, on behalf of the many Australians who have created and signed in support of the important matters that each petition concerns.
Thank you, Mr Speaker, and I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the Petitions Committee.
COMMITTEES
Tax and Revenue Committee
Report

Mr FALINSKI (Mackellar) (10:03): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Tax and Revenue, I present the committee report entitled The development of the Australian corporate bond market: a way forward together with the minutes of proceedings.

I know this will be the most important thing we do in this House today, not that the galahs up in level 2 will realise that or the media will report it or that this will lead to television news tonight, but the corporate bond market and the retail segment of it remain critical to the future of Australians, of Australian companies, of Australia's economy and for those Australians who are, at this moment, considering retiring. Too many good ideas in our nation are funded by taxpayers through the university system, through R&D grants and concessions in our tax system, and, just as they are getting ready to become commercially viable and successful ventures, they leave our shores for the primary reason of seeking capital in other countries that have access to risk capital. So, when you look at Atlassian for example, it was funded generously by the Australian taxpayer, but, when the point came when they were to become a successful commercial entity, they had to list on the Nasdaq in North America and then list on the London Stock Exchange. The reason for this is we don't have enough risk capital in Australia. The retail corporate bond market can help fix that problem.

Also, when you look at Australia, we have all the necessary blocks in place to be a major global centre for the bond market: we have a large pool of savings; we have a common law system of justice and governance through our court system that is both well-understood and is not biased or discretionary; and, most of all, we have a large number of skilled workers in this country and well-developed market systems, whether it be the Australian Stock Exchange or other market mechanisms that make bond markets so successful in the rest of the world.

Then, there are the demographics. Too many Australians find themselves having to invest as they get to the age of 55-plus—that's really old, Mr Speaker, as you know! Once you reach 55, that becomes a very old age! At that point you start thinking of retirement, you start thinking of how to live out those twilight years of your life, and it is important at that point in time that you have access to investments that can continue to give you a steady stream of income but do not have the downside of, say, bitcoin or the Australian Stock Exchange. So, it is important that we have these sorts of assets available for those Australians who about to commence their retirement years.

What are the blockages? Given that we are so well set up for these things, the blockages are all in the regulators. There is a form of tax that needs to be reformed by this parliament, but ASIC's active disinterest and discouragement in a retail corporate bond market, I think, verges on a derogation of their duty, and Treasury's inability and refusal to look at this area is extremely disappointing and a disservice to the Australian people.

When you look across the ditch in New Zealand, they undertook the reforms that our report is advocating. New Zealand, a much smaller nation than ours and without the structural advantages that our economy has, has a larger, broader, deeper, more liquid bond market than Australia does. This is unacceptable, at any level.
Finally, the chance for us to make this work is long overdue. It gives new meaning to the word 'urgent'.

I would like to thank the secretariat for all their help and assistance on this, especially during COVID when all of the hearings were done online. I'd like to thank the member for Kingsford Smith who came up with a catchy title to this report, which I know will live on long after I've stopped speaking, and, most of all, I would like to thank the parliament for making this investigation possible.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr THISTLETHWAITE (Kingsford Smith) (10:09): by leave—I also join with the chair of this committee, Mr Falinski, in commending the report to the parliament. Mr Falinski is right; Australia doesn't have enough of an appetite for risky investment in this country, and we have a fairly weak corporate bond market by comparison with other nations. A corporate bond, of course, is a debt security. It's issued by entities to finance their business operations. And, unlike equity, it doesn't dilute corporate ownership or ownership of the company. It's riskier than government bonds, and that's typically because it relies on the solvency of the company into the future. And the compensation, if you like, for the riskier nature is the offer of a higher coupon payment.

In terms of the Australian market, in 2019-20 the value of bonds issued by Australian corporate entities both domestically and offshore was $1.7 trillion. Most of that is held by large superannuation funds—about $60 billion worth of it. But 95 per cent of it is issued domestically to wholesale investors, who have to be registered with APRA and are known as sophisticated investors. There's very little to no offerings to retail investors through the ASX. One of the reasons for that is there's a complicated regulatory process that companies have to go through in terms of disclosure—offering a prospectus—before they can get on to the ASX. It has to be registered with ASIC. That's one of the factors the committee has identified as a barrier to more corporate bonds being issued here in Australia. So less than one per cent of corporate bonds held in Australia is owned by private investors—less than one per cent. Compare that to the United States, which we all know has that entrepreneurial investment ethos and culture, where 20 per cent of corporate bonds are held by private investors. So, there's a big difference. Even New Zealand has a much more liquid and deeper corporate bond market than Australia.

Is this something that we should be trying to encourage? Well, the committee is of the view that we should. And the reason is that, if you have more options for investment, you diversify that risk, you increase competition and there are better deals available. And ultimately you grow the pool of investment funds that are available and that, hopefully, spurs entrepreneurship, startups and investment in new jobs and new opportunities in this country.

So, what are the problems that the committee has identified? There's certainly a lack of awareness and understanding about how the corporate bond market works for retail investors in Australia, and that comes down to a lack of information and a lack of confidence. There are market access barriers. The minimum parcel and size of bonds that can be issued is $500,000. So most are not traded on the ASX directly. It's concentrated in banking, in finance and insurance, and less than five per cent of those that are offered is in other areas—for instance, manufacturing. The credit rating is generally only available to wholesale investors. There are onerous disclosure requirements. As I mentioned, you have to register with the ASX but also with ASIC. ASIC did issue a class order to streamline those disclosure requirements in 2014, but, according to KPMG's evidence to our committee, that process has failed and hasn't resulted in an increased take-up.

But the real issue in terms of why we don't have a deeper and more liquid corporate bond market in Australia is simply the taxation treatment; and it's the difference between the issue of shares and corporate bonds. Tax concessions are available on investment in shares in Australia. It's quite topical. It's known as dividend imputation. You get a franking credit for the tax paid by the company on the dividend for the amount, and it sometimes results in a refund. We all know about that on this side of the chamber. No such tax concession exists for corporate bonds. As a result, where do you think Australians put their money? They put their money where the tax concession is, and that is in shares.

Although we've made some great recommendations here, I think the reality is that, until you deal with that difference in the tax concessions between corporate bonds and shares, you're not going to get the uptake that you see in other nations throughout the world. So that's an issue that perhaps the parliament has to look at in the future. Nonetheless, this is a good report with some great recommendations around lowering the minimum investment amount, early redemption, the role of trustees and, of course, recommendations regarding disclosure requirements. I particularly point to the ASX submission, at paragraph 3.31 in the report, where they have issued some great recommendations regarding ASX 200 issuers with a term sheet and a cleaning notice and issuers outside of the ASX 200 with a reformed simple corporate bond prospectus, early redemption—which the committee has picked up—and removing anomalies and efficiencies in the existing two-part prospectus regime. They're some great recommendations that the government should look at. I commend the report to the House.

The SPEAKER: The time allotted for statements on this report has expired. Does the honourable member for Mackellar wish to move a motion in connection with the report to enable it to be debated on a later occasion?
Mr FALINSKI (Mackellar) (10:15): by leave—I move:
That the House take note of the report.
The SPEAKER: In accordance with standing order 39, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Reference to Federation Chamber
Mr FALINSKI (Mackellar) (10:15): I move:
That the order of the day be referred to the Federation Chamber for debate.
Question agreed to.
BILLS
Australian Federal Integrity Commission Bill 2021
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Dr Haines.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Dr HAINES (Indi) (10:17): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
I am pleased to reintroduce the Australian Federal Integrity Commission Bill 2021 to the House.
The purpose of this bill is as vital as it is simple: to establish a robust integrity commission to restore public trust, confidence and pride in the parliament and their democracy.
Now more than ever, we need to pass this bill.

The Australian Federal Integrity Commission model I've proposed in this bill would enable clear and practical responses to allegations of serious and systemic corruption issues at the federal level in the public interest.
In its most recent comprehensive review, the Centre for Public Integrity ranked this bill the best model of an integrity commission in the nation.
AFIC would have appropriate powers to receive referrals, assess allegations, conduct investigations and issue findings.
The bill specifically allows for public referrals.
It is vital that any Australian and all public servants have a reputable body that they can trust with corruption concerns and that will protect them as whistleblowers.
This bill provides just that.

As a safeguard, this bill also includes protections against frivolous, vexatious or otherwise baseless claims. These provisions would allow the commission to vet referrals and protect the reputations of all involved.
AFIC would be retrospective.

I want to be clear: this bill would not apply new laws to past facts. If conduct was criminal at the time, it was criminal at the time. All integrity commissions in this nation are retrospective, and this bill is no different in that regard.
We must be able to examine serious past conduct so we can learn from our mistakes and improve as a democracy.
AFIC also uses a clear, broad and sensible definition of corruption that is fit for purpose, and does not duplicate the work of our criminal justice system.
When it comes to investigations, AFIC must focus on conduct that is serious or systemic in nature.
AFIC will also be empowered to hold public hearings when in the public interest.

Over the past two years, I've spoken with many about their views on public hearings and I've incorporated concerns from both sides of this House into a balanced public interest test in part 5 of the bill to ease those concerns.
For example, all persons called to give evidence will have a rolling right to request a private hearing and can present their reasons for this in private with the commissioner.
